summary: 155 adult patients with confirmed infection of 2009 influenza A(H1N1) in 23 hospitals in china from October 1 to December 23, 2009. the most common organ dysfunctions included acute respiratory failure, altered mental status, septic shock, and acute renal failure. corticosteroids use was associated with a trend toward higher hospital mortality. 155 adult hospitalized patients with confirmed infection of 2009 influenza A(H1N1) in china from October 1 to December 23, 2009. a variable proportion of patients with 2009 influenza A(H1N1) infection were hospitalized [5], or both adult and pediatric patients [7,8], or all cases with confirmed, suspected, and probable diagnoses [8-10]. the heterogeneous patient population in the above studies might preclude the possibility of reporting valid risk factors for mortality. e-polymerase-chain-reaction (RT-PCR) assay performed at a laboratory operated under the auspices of the Chinese CDC. all reviewers were trained during a 1.5-hour course before the study. data were recorded: sex, age, major diagnosis, comorbidities, clinical presentation at symptom onset and on hospital admission, major laboratory results on hospital admission, complications, antiviral and antibiotic treatment, supportive treatment, and outcome. two separate models were constructed using stepwise conditional forward entry. one for demography, comorbidities, clinical presentations, and laboratory tests on admission. one for complications including organ failures and infections, if p 0.1. value Male sex 73 (57.0%) 17 (63.0%) 90 (58.1%) 0.570 organ failures during hospital stay included acute respiratory failure (40.0%), altered mental status (12.9%), septic shock (11.6%), and acute renal failure (9.7%). nonsurvivors were more likely to be treated with vasoactive agents, mechanical ventilation, and continuous renal replacement therapy. risk factors for hospital mortality by logistic regression analysis included diabetes (odds ratio [OR] 19.187) 8.738 (2.504 diabetes, serum level of LDH on hospital admission, septic shock, and altered mental status were independent predictors of hospital mortality. mortality seen in our study is significantly higher than those of hospitalized patients in the united states [7], united kingdom [14], and australia [15]. underlying medical conditions associated with complications from seasonal influenza have been consistently shown as risk factors. in a cohort of 1479 patients admitted to hospital with laboratory-confirmed pandemic (H1N1) influenza, patients with diabetes were at a higher risk of death, compared with those without diabetes. compared with 1266 hospitalized patients with the general population in France, Hanslik also found that diabetes was significantly associated with death. studies have shown that delayed antiviral treatment is associated with high risk of progression to severe disease such as ICU admission and respiratory failure. delay in antiviral treatment in our patients resulted in higher hospital mortality (17.4%) compared with the subgroup of adult hospitalized patients with 2009 influenza A(H1N1) in the united states. retrospective nature of this study precluded the possibility of integrating body mass index into our regression analysis model. the effect of underlying medical conditions and morbid obesity may not be independent. diabetes is reportedly up to seven times more prevalent in obese persons [34] so that the diabetic cases were most likely among obese patients. subgroup analysis of effect of corticosteroids treatment on hospital mortality. no external funding received in support of this study.
